image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives About this object

profileText: A Representative from New York; born in Troy, Rensselaer County, N.Y., January 1, 1902; attended the public schools and Colgate University, Hamilton, N.Y.; was graduated from Union University Department of Law, Schenectady, N.Y., in 1926; was admitted to the bar the same year and commenced practice in Troy, N.Y.; served as assistant United States attorney, northern district of New York, 1927-1930; chairman of the Rensselaer County Republican Committee, 1938-1952; delegate to the Republican National Convention in 1940; chairman, New York State Republican Committee, 1953-1954; trustee of Russell Sage College; director of the Union National Bank and of the Niagara Mohawk Power Co.; elected as a Republican to the Seventy-eighth and to the eight succeeding Congresses (January 3, 1943-January 3, 1961); was not a candidate for renomination in 1960 to the Eighty-seventh Congress; resumed the practice of law; died in Albany, N.Y., October 16, 1977; interment in Oakwood Cemetery, Troy, N.Y.

researchRecord.name: In the William Henry Hill Papers, ca. 1878-1964, 5 cubic feet.
In the New York Republican State Committee Records, 1888-2001, 5.39 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: Persons represented include Dean P. Taylor.

recordLocation.name: M. E. Grenander Department of Special Collections & Archives, University Libraries

researchRecord.name: In the Mathew "Harris" Ellsworth Papers, 1936-1956, 23.5 linear feet.
1924-1977, 43 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: The Dean Park Taylor Collection is organized into six series: correspondence, 1937-1977; scrapbooks, 1937-1963; books and recordings, 1924-1972; photographs and printed materials, 1926-1977; framed and signed photographs and printed materials; memorabilia, 1926-1977. The Correspondence series includes correspondence related to Taylor's chairmanship of the Rensselaer County Republican Committee, to issues of concern in the Congressional district in which he served and the New York State Republican Committee. His correspondents included Thomas E. Dewey, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Richard M. Nixon and many other prominent Republican leaders in New York and the United States. The Scrapbooks include clippings and photographs related to his political and Congressional careers. A finding aid is available in the repository.
